title: Skull Crusher
description:
The skull crusher is a highly effective exercise designed to target the triceps, specifically the triceps brachii muscle. It’s a great addition to any upper body workout routine, especially for those looking to build mass and strength in their arms. Here’s a breakdown of what you need to know about the skull crusher:
What is the Skull Crusher?
Type of Exercise: The skull crusher is a push exercise that isolates the triceps. It primarily works the triceps from the elbow up to the
latissimus dorsi muscle of the back.
Equipment: You can perform skull crushers using either a barbell, EZ-bar, or dumbbells. Each variation has its benefits, but they all effectively
target the triceps.
Benefits of Skull Crushers
Builds Tricep Mass: This exercise is excellent for increasing the size and strength of your triceps.
Improves Stability: It also helps in enhancing shoulder stability, which is crucial for overall upper body strength.
Versatile: Skull crushers can be incorporated into various workout routines, whether you’re focusing on arms, chest, or full-body workouts.
How to Perform Skull Crushers
Starting Position: Lie on a flat bench with your feet flat on the ground. Hold the barbell or dumbbells above your chest with your arms fully
extended.
Lowering the Weight: Slowly bend your elbows to lower the weight towards your forehead (hence the name "skull crusher"). Keep your upper arms
stationary.
Returning to Start: Extend your arms back to the starting position, squeezing your triceps at the top.
Tips for Proper Form
Control the Movement: Avoid letting the weight drop too quickly; control is key to prevent injury.
Keep Elbows In: Make sure your elbows stay close to your head throughout the movement to maximize tricep engagement.
Breathe: Inhale as you lower the weight and exhale as you lift it back up.
Recommended Sets and Reps
Start with 4 sets of 10 to 12 reps. Adjust the weight as you become more comfortable with the movement.
Incorporating skull crushers into your workout routine can significantly enhance your tricep development.

articles.title: DO's
list: Use a weight that allows you to maintain good form throughout the entire set.
Keep your elbows in close to your head.
Lower the weight slowly and in a controlled manner.
Squeeze your triceps at the top of the movement.
Breathe properly: Inhale as you lower the weight and exhale as you lift it back up.
Listen to your body: If you feel any pain, stop the exercise immediately.

articles.title: DONT's
list: Don't use a weight that is too heavy for you.
Don't let your elbows flare out to the sides.
Don't let your upper arms move during the exercise.
Don't forget to engage your core.
Don't ignore any pain you feel.
